project.name: releng
project.description: The official top-level project focused on coordinating and improving the creation of official releases of Gentoo Linux.
project.longdescription: Release Engineering ("releng") is the official Gentoo top-level project focused on coordinating and improving the creation of official releases of Gentoo Linux.
project.extraproject: The Gentoo Store is not an official Release Engineering sub-project, but the Store and Release Engineering coordinate very closely. All official Gentoo Linux releases are made available in the Gentoo Store. In addition, all maintenance releases are made available in the Gentoo Store as soon as possible, so that customers can benefit from the latest fixes and improvements.
Release Engineering for the x86 architecture.

Release Engineering maintains its own set of hardware for development, testing and release-building, as well as the porting of Gentoo Linux to new architectures. Currently, this hardware consists of a dual-CPU 900Mhz zx6000 Itanium 2 system with 10GB of RAM on extended loan from HP, an NForce3-based AMD64 system donated by NVIDIA, and a G4-based Mac. All systems are running Gentoo Linux, and access is provided to these systems for those interested in assisting the amd64, ppc and ia64 ports, as well as those in the general Linux/free software community who need access to these architectures to perform porting/QA work. If you are a developer (Gentoo Linux or otherwise) who could benefit from access to these boxes, please contact drobbins@gentoo.org.
project.goals: The goal of Release Engineering is to continually improve the quality, timeliness and overall procedures for creating official Gentoo Linux releases, as well as acting as the official coordinators for creating new Gentoo Linux releases. This project is very much focused on ensuring that the initial quality of every official release is as high as possible, and that the "from CD" experience is as positive for as many of our users as possible.

body.p: Every release consists of an offical version number, such as "1.4", and a number of architectures that are officially supported. Part of the Gentoo Linux release policy is to generally not hold up a release if certain less-popular architectures are not quite ready; therefore, an official release of Gentoo Linux may not offer builds for all the architectures for which there are ongoing development efforts.

body.p: The next official release of Gentoo Linux will adopt a new year-based versioning scheme and will be called Gentoo Linux 2004. It will be released in January 2004. It will also mark our transition to a quarterly (four times per annum) release schedule.

As of 4 Oct 2003, there has been one maintenanace release for 1.4 for x86, and a maintenance release for PowerPC is currently being created and will be available soon. After this, efforts will be directed towards Gentoo Linux 2004.

tr.ti: planned x86 rebuild, possible AMD64 release (with 2.6 kernel)

body.p: For the next release of Gentoo Linux, we will be transitioning to a date-based versioning scheme. The next Gentoo Linux release will be named "Gentoo Linux 2004."
Releng will be moving to a quarterly release schedule, with planned 2004 releases in:

We may release more often than this, depending on the need for maintenance releases. After the initial release of the year (2004), each subsequent release will be labeled with an ".1," ".2," ".3," suffix. This means that it is possible that we may have a 2004.4 or 2004.5 release.
The release of Gentoo Linux 2004 will mark a number of important transitions:

ul.li: Our transition to Gentoo Handbook install documentation for all architectures. The Gentoo Handbook is designed to provide a comprehensive guide covering all aspects of Gentoo Linux installation and, as it continues to be developed, usage.

The use of catalyst to build all stages, packages and LiveCDs for all architectures. The build process for Gentoo Linux 2004 will be fully scripted and automated for improved consistency, repeatability, maintainability, and to allow users to rebuild any release of Gentoo Linux using catalyst.

The introduction of official Release Notes for each architecture. The Release Notes will contain information related to the specific arch release, including improvements since last release, system requirements and compatibility information, errata and security fixes. The release notes will be actively maintained for each architecture until the next official Gentoo Linux release for this architecture is made, at which point they will be superceded by the new release notes.

In addition to Release Notes, we will also be implementing an XML-based GLSA system with XSL for HTML rendering of this data on our Web site. This will allow GLSAs to be referenced by URL from Release Notes.
2.6 kernels will be supported as an option on architectures that are ready to make this transition. In addition, updated 2.4 kernels will be offered where possible.

The XFCE4 desktop environment will be added to our official pre-built package offerings, bringing the number of desktop environments (other than window managers) offered by Gentoo to three (GNOME, KDE, XFCE4)
An OpenOffice 1.1 .tbz2 package will be included on all architectures that are able to support it. Gentoo Linux 1.4 provided an openoffice-bin package that did not function properly.
We will attempt to offer an official release for the AMD64 architecture.
We will mirror .tbz2s for each release on our mirrors, and document and support Portage's new "install packages from network" functionality.
We will have an active, coordinated release testing effort organized by the QA top-level project and the respective arch leads.
